2012 7:35 pm';'They should have featured the car I have just worked on...A Rover P5B Coupe.

It had been off the road for many years.

It ran but the brakes were siezed and the bodywork corroded in all the P5`s vunerable area`s.

I had it in the workshop for 15 day`s
8pm:
I carried out the work and was assisted for 5 day`s by a mechanic friend .

Work carried out ...

New inner
might be worth a look...?\n\n\n\nRJ':
middle and outer sills+ jacking points.

New a posts.

Front wings removed and inner wings repaired.

New front wing bottom repair sections fitted.

New D post`s inner and outer +associated metalwork repairs.

Rear boot repairs to wheelarches and battery box area.

New battery box.

New rear valance and local repairs.

Rear doors repaired.

Area`s next to front windscreen repaired.

Other frabrication repairs as required.

The bodyshell is now as solid as a rock.



My mechanic friend serviced the engine
column5: gearbox
column6:
rear axle and changed all fluids.

The braking system was completly renewed.

Bottom ball joints replced (not a straight forward fix).



I took it for it`s mot today and it passed first time.



We carried out the work without any drama or theatrical scenes.



Another Rover P5B saved from the banger boy`s.



                                  Gresham Flyer'

2012 9:21 pm';"'Just read this on another forum where someone wrote to Chanel 5 asking about the MGBGT...





 	  Quote:			  Update on the MBG being 2 or even 3 different cars
8pm:
I sent channel 5 questions which I don't have a copy of but along the lines of confirming if indeed the car was the same as the wreck ""rescued "" from the barn and about the validity of the 2 week restoration claim. This was the reply I recieved:







Dear David 



Thank you for your recent enquiry regarding Classic Car Rescue. 



While the production team were filming in Canada
might be worth a look...?\n\n\n\nRJ': the mechanics in London discovered some serious problems with the MGB
column5: midway through the restoration
column6: which meant they felt it might not be entirely safe to drive. Their original plan was to buy a new chassis
column7: which is a common way that people restore MGBs (you can buy an entire new monocoque chassis for just \xc2\xa31000) and build on top of that. But wanting to stick with used parts
column8: they bought another car and used the chassis from that
column9: transferring much of the first MGB
column11:
and windows. The cost of the second car was included in the figures mentioned and the end result was a combination of the two. 



The programme aims to show how Bernie Fineman and Mario Pacione cope with restoration jobs with a \xe2\x80\x9ctight deadline and an even tighter budget\xe2\x80\x9d in an entertaining fashion while also giving some background into why each selected model is held in the high regard that it is. It is not intended to
column13:
demonstrate the detailed effort and finance that can go into the high end restoration of classic cars. 



Nevertheless
column14:
this does not diminish the validity of your opinions and we are grateful to you for taking the time to make us aware of your concerns. Your comments have been logged in our Viewer Enquiries Report. This is circulated throughout the company and seen by all relevant personnel. 



Thank you for your interest in Channel 5. 



Yours sincerely 





Ian 

VIEWER ADVISOR'"

2012 4:53 pm';'Tonight:
2012 11:28 pm';"'I think the best of all these programmes either produced in the UK or in the USA was ""OVERHAULIN"".

Chip Foose is a prolific car builder in his own right and a likable guy.

The presenters Chris Jacobs and Courtney Hansen (later replaced by CJ) were very good as well.



They added a bit of comedy into the format and who could not shed a tear when the car was exposed to the owner and all that american hugging went on (and that was just the guys).

Even the rough tough car builders would all get emotional when hearing how pappa`s Chevy was now a memorial to his death.



Ok about 60 people were involved in the rebuild of these vehicles each time but they did it for real and the finished job was spot on...I would love to own one of these vehicles they must be priceless.



I understand the programme is returning this week 2nd Oct.



I also like watching Chasing Classic Cars with Wayne Carini
8pm:
a really enthusiastic sort of guy when it came to old automobiles. My name is Wayne Carini and I like chasing cars (as long as its not women said Mrs Carini) at least there is no spanner throwing and trantrums like some other programmes.



As for Salvage Squad I liked Claire Barrett who went on to restore a watermill with her husband in real life
might be worth a look...?\n\n\n\nRJ':
she was the sort of girl who liked to get DIRTY.!!!!



                                          Gresham Flyer'"
